What's happening is that the wave front in propagating in all directions except downward. There is downward pressure but it cannot go anywhere because of the tamping provided by the table the bottle is sitting on.

The pressure inside the bottle builds but the sides are closer to the point of detonation and so they experience higher pressure than above as the speed of the pressure wave though the non compressible liquid is roughly equal in all directions.

With the increased pressure, the sides fail. This provides a point for pressure to escape. As it does the now pressurized upper portion of the liquid volume suddenly experiences a reversal of movement as it seeks the point of low pressure. This results in the water mass rushing downwards towards the low pressure point while the equal and opposite reaction forces the upper bottle and cap upwards. Simultaneously, the escaping water creates a low pressure area at teh top of the bottle due to the downward rush of the fluid volume.

The combination of pressure reversals with their subsequent expansion and contraction of the bottle material provides the blown off cap (due to a pressure spike). However, it's interesting to note that the bottle material surrounding the cap is moving upwards while the cap is moving down at one point in the process. This is likely due to the non compressible fluid being forced upwards by the pressure wave and initially causing the material surrounding the cap to expand. THEN, with material expansion at maximum but the fluid inertia continuing forward, the low pressure in the lower portion of the bottle provides a pressure release through the center of the water column once the advancing column meets the terminus of the bottle interior with it's curved (even though roughly so) surface redirecting the flow towards the center and downward.....and thus towards the low pressure zone which then contributes to the downward flow.

Meanwhile the poor cap, it's stem mounted in the cross sectional center of now highly fatigued and stressed plastic, is dragged downwards through the weakend but still high pressure outer portion of the top of the bottle. As the shockwave is still advancing, the bottle cap then fails and is separated from the neck.

The reason here is because of the pressure wave switching between mediums (water and the air pocket in the top), waves behave differently between mediums, Im a SONAR technician for the US Navy so i will use my understanding of sound waves in the ocean to explain this the best i can. sound travels approximately 4800-5200 ft/sec in salt water, depending on the temperature of the water, the salinity, and the pressure of the water(caused by depth), sound waves attenuate at a logarithmic scale and when you have a sound wave change mediums you have whats called Di-polar attenuation,  expressed 40 log R, sound speed in air is approximately 1,125 ft/sec, (close to 4 times slower) if we assume that the pressure wave behaves similar to sound waves then you have some of the pressure wave bouncing off the surface of the water and some transferring into the air, the wave that bounces off the surface of the water and traveling back into the bottle moving about 4 time faster than the pressure wave in the air then causes a low pressure zone between the two waves traveling opposite directions, we call this a shadow zone, the low pressure then causes the compressible material (air) to collapse into the only space it can ( the shadow zone) and as it collapses it creates a high pressure zone and blows the lid off. I theorize that if you repeat this experiment with no air in the bottle that you will have a completely different outcome.

A few quick comments: 1) when pressure waves reflect off a pressure-release surface (water and air with a thin layer of plastic between probably meets this condition), they change polarity. The large positive pressure wave becomes a large negative pressure wave. Negative pressure waves are what generate cavitation. 2) The pressure waves don't necessarily have to be shocked in order to generate cavitation. 3) You are correct about the collapsing bubble at the top crushing the bottle by fluid inertia. When the bubble collapses, it carries the boundary of the bottle with it.

Here is my hypotheses as to why that happens :

Your way of thinking that explosion is supposed to increase the pressure is right, and indeed the total pressure inside the bottle do increase, but what you missed is the fact that the pressure isn't distributed evenly in the split second that the explosion happen.

So, when the explosion happen, it actually pushes a portion of the water sideward and downward, this direction is caused by the water's mass itself, making the majority of the explosion pushes downward instead of upward. The portion of the water that gets pushed to the bottom ended up pulling the water on the top and is the reason why the cap got pulled in.

Think of a syringe. When the explosion happen, it basically split the bottom half and the top half of the bottle into two parts, and it acts like when you pull a syringe to suck liquid.

The fact that the bottle is made of plastic and deformed upon explosion(the bottom half of the bottle gets bigger) also helps to make the vacuum effect on the top half of the bottle more apparent.

When the explosion happens, the sides closest to the point of detonation seem to bulge out the most. I think that because of how the water is moving, that bulge is what's making the cavity point in the water. In liquid state, water can't be compressed, so when a explosion happens, it pushes the water away. Because the explosion is at the bottom, the closest "walls" are the areas within a 2-3 in radius get puffed out because the water can't compress. This happens closer to the point of detonation because the shock hits it sooner. Because of that, the water farthest away from the impact has to fill the space. This water that's farther away has to move to fill that space, and the only way it can move in the opposite direction of the blast is through the creation of a low pressure cavity created from other molecules of water moving away from the point of detonation. This low pressure pulls the water in to fill it creating another low pressure region near the cap. That low pressure is what sucks the cap in to the point that it collapses.

A part that has me thinking though is that if you filled it completely, the oscillation of the water would be unnoticeable and the cap would fly off sooner.

This is good footage but your frame rate is so low the initial shock wave of the blast has already passed upward and been reflected back down by the second frame.  To demonstrate what I am saying you say at one point, "the bubbles form all over the bottle at the sane time."  They don't.  What they do is form on the back side of the pressure wave as it moves through.  They are caviatation bubbles, or little bubbles of vacuum.  Then they collect in the middle because the shock wave strikes a non-flat surface at the top of the bottle and is reflected back in several direction.  The impact of the shock wave on the cap has driven it upward and it starts to rebound downward at the same time the rest of the bottle is accelerating upward.  It is called the pogo effect and was a real problem for the Apollo missions.  The bottom of the rocket accelerates faster than the top.  The mass of the top pushes the bottom back down while it is accelerating.  The rocket gets shorter.  Then the top accelerates as the bottom is slowing down.  The rocket gets taller.  Wash, rinse, repeat, until the rocket stabilizes.  You bottle is experiencing very bad pogo effect, well beyond its stress rating.

There are two sources of propagation of the shock wave. One is the water itself moving. That is the gross movement of water that you see in your photographs. The other is the energy propagated THROUGH the water and that is the sonic shock wave.

According to the measurements of the raw video, the cup experiences the acceleration of about 10^5 m/s^2. For the mass of the cup and nearby stuff at least 10g and the effective frontal area of the bottle around 5 cm^2 the required pressure difference should be at least 10^6=10atm. That is very unlikely to be the case since the space under the cup is filled with air, which is unable to posess negative pressure.

I suppose, this shows that the suction of any kind cannot provide this effect alone.

This explanation agrees with numbers way more: bigger bottles may undergo the pressure of several atms and then they tear along themselves while tearing the upper part from the lower requires even more forse.

Now detonations cause shock waves, but contrary to common belief those shockwaves not only contain a sharp pressure rise, but also a noticeable amount of underpressure or rarefaction wave. That's why you will sometimes find objects, being placed near to an explosion, being pulled near the explosion than being pushed away (e.g. the blinds being mounted on a window often seem to be pulled out of the house when an explosion occurs nearby.
In addition, underwater explosions are very special in their physical behavior - water bubbles form and collapse in an oscillating way (the time of one of those cycles and the bubble diameter are acutally used to measure the strength of an underwater explosive charge).

You can see that near the bottom where the explosion initiates, the bottle expands outward from the force. This creates a temporary vacuum at the top as the bottle hasn't yet broken. Its like a bellow for a fire expanding to pull in air but there is nowhere to pull from as the container is still, momentarily, sealed. This creates the downward force on the top of the bottle from the atmospheric pressure and the cavitation ensues due to the low vacuum pressure. Once the walls break the pressure goes back the other direction to find equilibrium again. The curves near the top of the bottle are the weakest structural point of the shape and therefore are the spots that collapse under the vacuum.
The detonation moves the bottom apart, so it creates low pressure inside the bottle (the cap being pulled in), but when the pressure goes back to normal it creates a slingshot effect.

It happens because of Newton's first law of inertia. The bottle blows up from the bottom shooting the bottle up so fast that the top of it doesn't have enough time to react and it wants to stay in place. The bottom is moving super fast while the top is just standing there barely moving. It's like when you pull the table cloth out from under a bunch of glassware. The sheet is pulled so fast, that the glassware doesn't have time to react because of Newton's first law (an object in motion tends to stay in motion and an object at rest tends to stay at rest).    That is my theory.

Absolutely, similar to the Venturi effect, since the force is directed laterally due to the mechanical failure of the charge at the center, as the force pushes outward, it creates a low pressure effect on the center axis. Ok so I'm using my wife's account watching this. Personally I'm a demolitions explosive in the military, don't get me wrong I'm not a civilian explosive engineer, however at my level of education I have had extensive training and education on the matter. From my understanding is that an explosive is defined as a gas that expands equally in all directions, however it travels the path of least resistance, I.E. If I set it on the ground, most the force with travel in a half orb away from the ground, as opposed to if I throw it in the air, the explosive force would travel in more of a sphere.  Also, once the explosion occurs, it causes what's called over pressure, there are four types of over pressure, direct, indirect, reflective, and residual. Direct is the total pressure of the explosive ( depending on the distance you are from the point of ignition) incidental is half the pressure after passing around defilade (cover, such as a wall or door) reflective is the pressure that bounces of a solid object and doubles, however decreases in pressure much more rapidly, (say there is a corner three feet from an explosion, by the time the pressure wave hit the first wall in the corner, it may be at 3 ft lbs of pressure, when it bounces off the wall it will immediately be 6 ft lbs of pressure, however it will dissipate much more quickley and by the time it hits the wall a few inches away it may only be at 1 ft lbs of pressure, where it will obviously turn into 2 ft lbs of pressure and dissipate once the negative and positive pressures in the area are equalized. And lastly there is residual pressure, this is the overall pressure left after an explosion in an area (particularly enclosed areas) this pressure can actually be felt in rooms shortly after a charge has detonated until the pressure in that room equalizes. Another phenomenon that occurs when dealing with explosives and overpressure is what happens to the surrounding pressure once there is an ignition. You see pressure is relatively equal depending on altitude and climate, and a few other factors but I'll wait for that. When an explosion occurs it pushes all the pressure outwards and creates a negatively pressurized void or orb, once the negative pressure expands to the point that the positive pressure is equal (this primarily depends on how violent the explosion was) it stops, then positive pressure rushes in, however to put it in laments terms it rushes in to quickly and creates negative pressure around it, so it has to expand again, and the process is repeated (very quickly mind you) until the pressure is returned to normal, if you would like to see an excellent demonstration of this watch a video of nuclear test and pay attention to the trees, notice how they bend all the way one way, as the dust rushes past them, and then back again, as the dust rushes back, they keep doing this back and forth rapidly and a little less each time until they are back to normal. What I believe is causing the collapse of the kid is a combination of both theories. What is interesting about using an explosive, and I use that term lightly in this case as black powder is hardly an explosive, however creates the perfect subject in this case, in a case, and in water which is much more dense than air, is that essentially you are creating an environment that creates all four types of overpressure very rapidly, keep in mind that reflective pressure also bounces off other pressure waves, I believe this is why you see the bubbles forming in an single area, now with the explosive being on the bottom of the bottle and the design if the bottle, I believe that the explosives least resistant path is on the bottom, and that is why the bottom blows out, from the sides obviously, now with the top being much stronger than the bottom what we are seeing essentially is reflective pressure from the waves hitting the too and coming down, and residual pressure of the negative pressure and positive pressure trying to equalize very quickly, I also believe with the water rushing from the bottom of the bottle, it is essentially pulling the water out of the bottom, which creates another negative void in the top of the bottle, (which is why the lid comes down) now remember that reflective pressure I keep talking about? And the fact that pressure takes the path if least resistance? Well I believe this pushes the weaker walls of the battle up around the lid as the reflective pressure bounces back. Now like I said I don't have a degree in the science and mechanics of this, and those that do could probably tear my hypothesis apart, however from my understanding and experience with explosives and overpressure I believe you created an extensive and quite unique environment to study an explosion, I would like to see how different objects would react when filled with water and blown up, as well as to how the explosive reacts in open water and at different depths, temperatures, and pressures. I believe that would open up some more questions and theories.

I agree with the negative pressure theory for this reason: The shockwave was spherical emanating from the bottom of a cylinder of water. There is a moment where the force of the explosion creates pressure compressing the matter around it.  The yet uncompressed matter is temporarily drawn into the area once occupied by now compressed matter until the compression limit is reached by the expanding shockwave.  I imagine this to be like whipping a rope,  inducing a wave in rope, pulls connected units to pass energy along it. Though the rope does not physically get shorter,  the wave induced shortens its linear distance by a function of that wave.  The vacuum at the end of the cylinder is the end of the wave's rope shortening, but it will eventually whip when the energy reaches the end of the rope and carry the shockwave radii onward and outward.  To test this hypothesis, I propose a central charge in a spherical vessel, where evenly spread negative pressure would not appear as forcefully, a smaller vessel/larger charge whose shockwave would breech before the opportunity for a differential to be observed, or a pinprick in upper neck of the same cylindrical vessel through which air would be pulled in the moment of negative pressure, and expelled as the shockwave arrived.  Of further interest would be to suspend a vertical, centered 'necklace' of compressible capsules, be vitamin E or other gel based capsules to see the effect the advancing shockwave has on each capsule as it moves through the liquid. The low pressure that sucks the top of the bottle in is probably caused by inertia of the water. As the expanding gas and water push on the bottom of the bottle, the latter accelerates up as the force is transmitted through the sides. However, the water in the bottle is much heavier and stays in place. As a result, the air bubble at the top is expanded, and the resulting low pressure sucks the cap in. Once the water gets going, the pressure in the top equalizes.

I think it has to do with the most efficient ratio of surface area containing a volume being a sphere.  Before the bottle fails, it tries to expand in every possible direction, but in order to do this, it must either stretch the material thinner or draw it from somewhere else.  The most inefficient ratio of volume to surface is at the thinnest diameter, or the bottleneck.  It 'shrank' in order to contain more of the pressure, but the vessel failed before it was completely reshaped.

To add onto that, you can see from the highspeed that the top cap stands still until it gets just about surpassed by the rest of the bottle's circular plastic, at which point it is pulled along by it. A long circular tube of plastic is hard to break, especially when the bomb is pushing it OUTWARD at the point of explosion, and forward at the same time.

I think I know why it happens.

The cap and top of the bottle's plastic is thicker and the cap and top of the bottle is by far the heaviest part of the entire bottle.

When the bomb goes off, the circular shape of the plastic bottle is very hard to break and ripple and the natural direction it will want to go is forward or backwards, NOT side to side. Breaking the circular plastic from the shock alone is also difficult.

So basically, the weight of the top and the circle shape cause that effect.

I have a theory for you !
When the firecracker bursts at the bottom of the bottle, it pushes all the water besides it downards, so you have a strong downwards force. You can't uncompress water, it creates space between molecules, vacuum => cavitation. When the bubbles want to collapse, they apply a force in every direction towards their center, but they can't pull upwards, because the strong force of the explosion is still there, so they pull downwards and tract the cap with them.
